ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I really built out my vocabulary of Spanish and improved my understanding of when to use certain verb tenses. I also feel like I am able to say things without translating in my head first.
This was the first time I took a language every day of the week, which meant I had a recurring class every day. This helped me improve my time management and scheduling skills.

I learned to speak in the imperfect, future, subjunctive, affirmative, and negative tenses, which were completely new concepts to me. We learned alot more vocabulary and went more in-depth into the preterite. We also learned about past and present participles, which were pretty cool.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I've taken language classes from kindergarten through 12th grade and this was by far, the best language course I've taken. In my experience, language courses tend to be super repetitive but this course was very engaging. I think the main downside was the speed of the material. We would often learn complex material in just a couple days and then move on but I think to learn it for the long-term, it would be helpful to spend more time in each unit.

I think the logistics of the asynchronous day could be improved, in terms of clarity of assignments and expectations for the asynchronous day. I also think that the supersite could have been better aligned with the materials we were discussing in class.

I wish that the professors had more autonomy on how to go about the course instead of having to strictly adhere to the online setup of this course. I like profe Mayte's teaching methods a lot, and I think I would have been able to learn more through her instead of the egg man of VHL (no offense to him). I asked for extra credit, but that is not allowed. If it was up to her, she would have let me do extra credit. Also, I was in a section where we had a little bit more extra work since we participated in a study, and it would have been nice if we could have received some form of extra credit for that (but of course, we did not). I love Spanish, but I miss how I learned it in middle school. It was more effective, and more stuck. The Spanish here is way more intensive and crammable, which is not the best as far as retention of content goes. Instead of focusing on what was being taught, I found myself just scrambling to get the big load of homework done, even if that meant to understanding everything the way I would have preferred. The actual content is not hard to learn, but the format is what makes it intensive.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It is a very time-consuming class given that it meets four days a week so I'm not sure that I would recommend it unless someone had a requirement. However, if they did have a requirement, I would definitely recommend Mayte as a professor she was wonderful!
I would recommend this course to another student, I think it significantly improved my Spanish speaking, writing, and auditory abilities.
I would recommend this course to another student, specifically with Mayte. I enjoy Spanish, and I like that I completed this course because of study abroad opportunities as well.
